recipes.description: The Nigerian Party Jollof Rice needs no introduction. There simply isn't an event in Nigeria without it. In the lifetime of an average Nigerian, the party jollof rice would have been eaten in thousands of portions.
recipes.title: Party Jollof Rice
ingredients: 4 Fresh tomatoes or one 14.5oz can of diced tomatoes
crayfish (optional, but I love to use it)

recipes.description: A hot and spicy broth made with a choice of meat (chicken/beef/goat and sometimes lamb) or fish (usually catfish). Seasoned with a blend of aromatic and authentic African spices. Mostly served with yam, bread, plantain, potatoe, rice or eaten 'as is'.
recipes.title: pepper soup
ingredients: 1.25kg of ‘soup’ (hard) chicken or goat meat, cut in bite-sized pieces
Ground red chilies/ cayenne pepper, to taste

recipes.description: Egusi soup is a classic Nigerian staple soup enjoyed in various forms across the country. It is usually served with swallows like Eba, Amala, Semovita, Pounded yam, Fufu, and the likes. It doubles as Nigeria’s favorite and also the most popular soup in Nigeria. Present in all Nigerian Restaurants.
recipes.title: Egusi (Melon Seed) Soup

recipes.description: A very popular quick and easy to make West African street food, similar to doughnuts. Dangeroulsy delicious and addictive. The puff puff is both fun to make and eat. It comes in a sweet and a peppered variety. Although the sweet version is more popular, I personaly like the kick of this version.
recipes.title: Pepper Puff Puff

recipes.description: A delicious pastry filled with minced meat, potatoe and carrots. The outer bit is slighty flaky and very rich in flavour while the filling is very moist and appetizing. A must try ultimate comfort food.
recipes.title: Meat Pie

recipes.description: A popular accompanying dish in Nigeria. It is commonly served with Jollof Rice, Fried Rice, Fried Plantain, Custard, Akamu (Pap, Ogi) etc or can be eaten alone as a snack. Due to its popularity, Moi Moi is often served at parties, dinners and other special occasions
recipes.title: Moi Moi (Beans Pudding)

recipes.description: Okpa is a cheap, very filling, delicious and healthy on-the-go food especially for people on a diet or diabetics. The secret to making the best okpa is to use as few ingredients as possible because okpa beans (Bambara nuts) have a natural delicious flavour, which is ruined by adding a lot of seasoning.
recipes.title: Okpa (Bambara Pudding)
ingredients: 1/2 cup or 15 tablespoons of palm oil

recipes.description: A mouth watering delicacy peculiar to the Igbo tribe of Nigeria. It is by far the easiest and quickest soup to prepare, making it the choice soup for impromptu guests.
recipes.title: Nsala (White) Soup
ingredients: 2 Tablespoons Dry Ground Pepper or 3 Fresh Yellow Atarodo

recipes.description: Nothing warms up a weekend breafast like a plate of old faithful akara stuffed in freshly baked bread (Agege bread) and served with a bowl of akamu (pap - fermented corn pudding). Akara is similar to moi moi (since they both have a pureed beans base) and almost as popular a favorite street food as puff puff.
recipes.title: Akara (Bean Fritters)
